title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" designates amounts for the reduction of public debt under Subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes a new part titled "DESIGNATION FOR REDUCTION OF PUBLIC DEBT" with section 6097 outlining the designation process. Section 6097 of the Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their adjusted income tax liability to reduce the public debt. This designation must be made when filing tax returns and is separate from any contributions to the Presidential Election Campaign Fund. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on the Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to pay off federal government obligations included in the public debt. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are appropriated to the Trust Fund for this purpose. Any obligation paid with Trust Fund amounts is canceled and retired, and cannot be reissued. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations included in the public debt. Amendments made by this section apply to amounts received after the enactment of this Act. Part C of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a new section for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration procedures are mandated within 15 days after Congress adjourns, with reductions based on estimated tax revenues and adjustments for discretionary spending and deficit changes. All U.S. accounts are subject to dollar reductions unless exempted. Sequestration procedures mandate reductions in U.S. accounts based on estimated tax revenues and discretionary spending. Obligational authority is reduced permanently, with exemptions for certain accounts like Social Security and interest payments. The amendments made by this section will not be subject to the expiration date set forth in the Act. The amendments made by this section will cease to have any effect after the first fiscal year with no public debt.
